If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would approach this as a repeated game where the goal is to maximize my payoff over the long run. Let's analyze the possible outcomes:

1. If I always pick R (45$ per round) and my opponent always picks B (35$ per round), I will make 900$ more than them over 75 rounds, which is significant. However, this strategy assumes that my opponent will consistently choose B, which may not be the case if they are also trying to maximize their payoff.
2. If I always pick R (45$ per round) and my opponent chooses a mixed strategy, I might end up with less than 900$ over 75 rounds due to the times when my opponent picks R.
3. If I choose a mixed strategy, say picking R 60% of the time and B 40% of the time (for simplicity), my expected payoff per round would be:
    - 0.6 * (45$ if opponent picks R, 0$ otherwise) + 0.4 * (35$ if opponent picks R, 40$ otherwise) = 27$ + 14$ * P(opponent picks B), where P(opponent picks B) is the probability that my opponent picks B when I pick R.
    - If we assume that my opponent is rational and follows a similar strategy (picking B 60% of the time and R 40% of the time), their expected payoff per round would be:
      0.6 * (35$ if I pick R, 0$ otherwise) + 0.4 * (40$ if I pick R, 35$ otherwise) = 21$ + 5$ * P(I pick B), where P(I pick B) is the probability that I pick B when my opponent picks R.

Now, to maximize my long-term payoff, I want my expected payoff per round to be higher than my opponent's. To do this, I can try to increase the probability that my opponent picks B when I pick R (P(opponent picks B)) and decrease the probability that I pick B when my opponent picks R (P(I pick B)).

However, without knowing the exact strategy my opponent will use, it's difficult to predict their behavior precisely. I could choose a mixed strategy based on empirical observations or assumptions about their behavior, but ultimately, the best choice would depend on how they play. In this case, I might choose R more frequently because 45$ per round is a higher payoff than 35$, even though it carries the risk of earning nothing if my opponent also picks R.
